## a.
This task aims to calculate the earnings per share and the price-earnings ratio for no net present value after the Firm merger.

Now, if we consider that the **Net Present Value** of the acquisition is zero, then the ***present value of the incremental cash flows is equal to the present value of the Firm Butter***. Therefore, to determine the new **Price per Share** we will use the values of **Earnings** and $\operatorname{EPS}$ reported for the Firm Butter:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Price per Share}&=\frac{\text{Earnings} \times\operatorname{EPS}_{\text{ Butter}}}{\text{Shares outstanding}}\\[10pt]
&=\frac{\$690,000\times12.7}{170,333}\\[10pt]
&=\$51.4463
\end{align*}
$$

So let's go back to formula $(2)$ and let's calculate the **Price-earning ratio** after the merger:

$$
\begin{align*}
\operatorname{PE}&=\frac{\text{Price per Share}}{\text{Earnings per share}_{\text{After Merge}}}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$51.4463}{\$5.4012}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{9.525}
\end{align*}
$$

So the **Price-earning ratio after the merger** is about $9.525$.

## b.
The goal of this task is to calculate the synergy between the firms.

The $\operatorname{NPV}$ can be calculated as the difference between the **total value of Firm Bread to Firm Butter** and the **cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition**:

$$
\operatorname{NPV}=V^{*}_{\text{Bread}}-\text{Cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition}
$$

Where 

$V^{*}_{\text{Bread}}$ is the total value of Firm Bread to Firm Butter.


Now, let's recall that in this merge, the **Net Present Value** $(\operatorname{NPV})$ is zero. Therefore:

$$
\begin{align*}
0&=V^{*}_{\text{Bread}}-\text{Cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition}\\[10pt]
V^{*}_{\text{Bread}}&=\text{Cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition}
\end{align*}
$$

But, the total value of Firm Bread to Firm Butter is the sum of the market value of Firm Bread and the **Synergy** $(\Delta V)$.
$$
V_{\text{Bread}}^{*}=V_{\text{Bread}}+\Delta V
$$

So we have an expression for the **acquisition cost of the firm Bread** as a function of its **Market Value** and the **incremental net gain from the acquisition**:

$$
\text{Cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition}=V_{\text{Bread}}+\Delta V
$$

Now, let's manipulate this equation and get an expression to find the **Synergy**:

$$
\begin{equation}
\text{Synergy}=\text{Cost to the firm Butter of the acquisition}-V_B
\end{equation}
$$

Now, the **cost of the firm Butter of the acquisition** (in this case, this amount is also the **total value of Firm Bread to Firm Butter**) can be calculated by the product of the **Price per share after merger** and the number of shares received:

$$
\begin{align*}
V^{*}_{B}&=\text{Price per share}\times\text{Received shares}\\[10pt]
&=\$51.4463\times\left(73,000\times\frac{1}{3}\right)\\[10pt]
&=\$1,251,859.97
\end{align*}
$$

Now, the market value of Firm Bread can be determined as the product of the 
**Price-earnings ratio** and its **Earnings**:

$$
\begin{align*}
V_{B}&=\text{Price-earnings ratio}\times\text{Earnings}\\[10pt]
&=\$230,000\times6.35\\[10pt]
&=\$1,460,500
\end{align*}
$$

Notice that the hypothesis of a null $\operatorname{NPV}$ leads us to a negative value of synergy!

Let's say we could look at this from two perspectives:
- If it has been a surprise to Butter that the value of the merger of the two firms is less than the value of the sum of the two firms, then it is very likely that the cause is given by problems between the leadership of the two companies. 

- If Firm Butter decides to combine with Firm Bread knowing that the offer will bring a negative synergy, it is likely that it is looking for a legal way to reduce its tax obligations.
